G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and was responsible for the maintenance and repair of common areas and security-related building entry doors at the Premises.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and was responsible for the maintenance and repair of common areas and security-related building entry doors at the Premises.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea Division of the Massachusetts District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the damages sought are within the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea Division of the Massachusetts District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the damages sought are within the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue in the Chelsea District Court is proper because the rental property that is the subject of this action is located in Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to these claims occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease and tenancy in Massachusetts carries with it a covenant of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: In addition, to the extent applicable, Defendant’s failure to maintain adequate security in the common areas may also constitute a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including 105 C.M.R. 410.480 and related sections requiring maintenance of egress and building security, which in turn supports the claim for breach of quiet enjoyment and statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

105 C.M.R. 410.480.proposition: In addition, to the extent applicable, Defendant’s failure to maintain adequate security in the common areas may also constitute a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including 105 C.M.R. 410.480 and related sections requiring maintenance of egress and building security, which in turn supports the claim for breach of quiet enjoyment and statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑ and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law even if not expressly stated in the lease, and protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly refers to an “implied warranty of quiet enjoyment” and treats it as an implied covenant in the residential leases, notwithstanding any express language. The court further explains that a breach occurs where the landlord’s conduct, or what the landlord permits or fails to control, results in substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment, here through pervasive late-night noise that made the apartments not reasonably habitable. This directly supports both that the covenant is implied by law and that it protects against serious interference with use and enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: "He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge... There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done."

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982);.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law even if not expressly stated in the lease, and protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982);.support_reasoning: The court expressly explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment,” including that the phrase comes from landlord-tenant law and refers to freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the premises. It further states that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment, confirming that the covenant is implied by law even if not written into the lease. This directly matches the proposition about an implied covenant protecting tenants from serious interference with their use and enjoyment of leased premises.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982);.relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law even if not expressly stated in the lease, and protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes an implied obligation arising from the lease that the lessor will refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, which is a formulation of an implied covenant protecting quiet and beneficial enjoyment. The court further explains that the same acts may be both a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and an independent wrong interfering with the tenant’s peaceful enjoyment. This directly supports the idea that such a covenant is implied even if not expressly stated and protects against serious interference with use and enjoyment.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought….”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994);
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law even if not expressly stated in the lease, and protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court explicitly describes the covenant of quiet enjoyment (under G.L. c. 186, § 14) as protecting a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the tenancy, i.e., with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises. While this case arises under the statutory covenant, Massachusetts law treats quiet enjoyment as a standard incident of residential tenancies, and the court analyzes it without requiring any special express lease language, thus treating it as an implied protection of the tenancy. The holding squarely aligns with the proposition’s description of the covenant’s function and scope.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880, 884 (1988). Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987). Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 167 (1985). Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102.”}

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law even if not expressly stated in the lease, and protects the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion directly characterizes the failure to provide heat as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and discusses that liability arises based on the landlord’s conduct that seriously impairs the character and value of the premises, not on intent. While the case is framed through G.L. c. 186, § 14, it relies on and reaffirms common-law quiet enjoyment principles, protecting the tenant from serious interference with use and enjoyment of the premises regardless of any express lease term. This aligns with the proposition’s description of the covenant and its protective scope.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.raw_text: *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782, 790–91 (1994) (appearing in text as part of a list);
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that serious interferences with safety, security, or habitability, when caused or allowed to persist by the landlord after notice, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to repair serious sanitary, building, and fire code violations after notice, where it is foreseeable that the failure would substantially impair the value of the premises as a dwelling, constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). The court emphasizes that omissions such as failure to repair known defects frequently violate § 14 and that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling. This directly supports the proposition that serious, unremedied interferences with safety, security, or habitability amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. See Simon v. Solomon… (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.… (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas… (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and to keep it so). A ‘landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,’ Blackett v. Olanoff… on the question whether there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.raw_text: *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997) (appearing in text as part of a list);
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that serious interferences with safety, security, or habitability, when caused or allowed to persist by the landlord after notice, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct and emphasizes that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects—problems the landlord has notice of—has repeatedly been held to violate § 14. It cites prior cases (Simon, Darmetko, Dorgan, Cruz, Doe) as examples where known conditions affecting habitability or safety, left unaddressed, constituted breaches. This aligns with the proposition that serious interferences with safety, security, or habitability, allowed to persist after notice, breach the covenant.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). … [I]n each case since the 1973 statutory revision … there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
